By the King. A proclamation for the better execution of the office of His Maiesties Exchanger, and reformation of sundry abuses and fraudes practised vpon his Maiesties coynes. England and Wales. Sovereign (1625-1649 : Charles I) Charles I, King of England, 1600-1649.
5 sheets (versos blank).
by Bonham Norton and Iohn Bill, printers to the Kings most excellent Maiestie, Imprinted at London : M. DC. XXVII. [1627]
Appointing Henry Rich, Earl of Holland, to the post of Exchanger. Dated at end: ... White-Hall the fiue and twentieth day of May, in the third yeere of our reigne ... . Arms 11; Steele notation: currant clamatiōs 2) disturbance 3) particu- 4) worke- 5) conuerted for. Reproduction of original in the British Library.
=======

5 sheets (versos blank).
by Bonham Norton and Iohn Bill, printers to the Kings most excellent Maiestie, Imprinted at London : M. DC. XXVII. [1627]
Appointing Henry Rich, Earl of Holland, to the post of Exchanger. Dated at end: ... White-Hall the fiue and twentieth day of May, in the third yeere of our reigne ... .
